title: What sound would you choose for an electric car to make on the move?
text:
All new electric cars will be fitted with devices that create a noise from 2021 – and plans have been laid out to let drivers choose the sound their vehicle makes.

Battery-electric and hybrid models that can be driven silently will need to have an acoustic vehicle alert system (Avas), so pedestrians can hear them coming, under both EU and US rules.

Noises are currently being set by car makers but in a move that could change the game for owners in the UK, Europe and the States, the US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said owners should be able to ‘select the sound they prefer from the set of sounds installed in the vehicle’.

So, given the choice, what would you choose? Drivers have been having their say online this week: inevitably some might like a V8 rumble, but opinions ranged from Star Wars TIE Fighters to Rick Astley's 1980s hit, Never Gonna Give you Up.

Making plenty of sound: Transport bosses in the UK say electric car owners should be able to choose what fake noise their electric car makes. What would you select?

All brand new electric and hybrid models type approved from 1 July 2019 have been required to have one of the acoustic devices fitted under recent EU regulations.

Meanwhile, manufacturers have until 2021 to make sure all brand new electric cars sold have the devices, not just new models coming to market.

These rules will be compulsory in the UK, no matter the outcome of Brexit, the Department of Transport has confirmed.

In the US, the rules are being applied a year earlier, meaning all electrified models will need to produce a noise at slow speeds from 2020.

The new laws make it compulsory for the devices to activate when vehicles are reversing or travelling at speeds up to 12.5mph.

However, drivers will be able to switch the fake sound off if they deem it appropriate – for example in slow-moving traffic in a motorway jam.

Until now, it has been claimed that the noise devices make will mimic the sound of a conventional engine - though there hasn’t been much evidence of this from different car makers.

Jaguar has already been working with Guide Dogs for the Blind to develop a tone for the I-Pace SUV that is easy for the trained K-9s to hear.

Mercedes-Benz - which had previously worked with rock band Linkin Park to produce bass-heavy sounds - has a totally different artificial humming noise that it will use across its EQC range and VW’s recently-revealed ID.3 has just one fake tone that reportedly also has a different note.

Porsche, somewhat cheekily, is offering a noise upgrade on its new £116,000 Taycan, with an ‘Electric Sport Sound’ part of the optional extras list at a staggering price of £354.

Jaguar has been working with Guide Dogs for the Blind to develop sounds that are easy for trained K-9s to hear

The noise is four years in the making and designed to be audible for pedestrians but not heard by those inside the vehicle, Jaguar says

Now the US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has said that motorists should be able to choose the soundtrack their electric vehicle plays.

It is currently considering if manufacturers should be able to limit the number of fake sounds they can install as options in new models, and also if they need to prevent drivers from being able to upload their own tunes.

An NHTSA agency spokesperson told The Verge that it had ’requested public comment on amending the new Quiet Vehicle safety standard FMVSS No. 141, Minimum Sound Requirements for Hybrid and Electric Vehicles’ with the vision to ‘allow multiple driver-selectable sounds so long as they meet the existing performance requirements’.

They added: ‘NHTSA is considering whether to allow hybrid and electric vehicles to be equipped with a suite of pedestrian alert sounds from which a driver may select a preference.’

One popular electric-car sound was the high-pitched TIE Fighter from Star Wars films

The big question is, what fake noise would you want your electric car to produce? People have been sharing their favourites on social media.

A couple of people tweeted they’d want their vehicle's note to replicate the TIE Fighters from Star Wars, while another said they’d choose the soundtrack of a stampede of bison.

Another opted for the Jetsons’ spaceship while others chose screaming, blowing raspberries and even Fred Flintstone’s Yabba DaddaDoo.

The most unusual choice, however, was someone wanting Rick Astley’s 1987 number one hit, Never Gonna Give You Up, played on repeat each time they start the car up.

Electric cars are a 'silent menace', say campaigners

When discussing the introduction of Avas devices, Michael Ellis, the former roads minister, said back in July: 'The Government wants the benefits of green transport to be felt by everyone, and understands the concerns of the visually impaired about the possible hazards posed by quiet electric vehicles.'

The law was also welcomed by charities and campaigners including Guide Dogs for the Blind, which said electric cars are 40 per cent more likely to hit a pedestrian than a normal vehicle.

Spokesman John Welsman said: 'There are two million children and adults living in the UK affected by sight loss and the rise in electric and hybrid vehicles pose a significant risk to them... We are delighted that from today it is now compulsory for new models to have an Avas built in.'

However, Chris Hanson-Abbott, a vehicle safety campaigner and founder of Brigade Electronics said the government’s recent 'Road Safety Statement for 2019 – A Lifetime for Road Safety' report failed to acknowledge the dangers electric cars loom until Avas devices are mandatory for all models in 2021.

Vehicle safety campaigners said the government should highlight the dangers of electric cars to pedestrians and those with visual impairments

Describing electric cars as a ‘silent menace’, Hanson-Abbott said: ‘The fact there is no requirement to fit any system means there are hundreds and thousands of electric and quiet vehicles on Britain’s roads which pose a danger to vulnerable road users.

‘Owners of electric vehicles should think about fitting an AVAS themselves if they don’t want to add to the toll of deaths and injuries on our roads.’

There are currently around 227,000 electric and plug-in hybrid cars on UK roads today, according to experts.

And RoadPeace – the national charity for road crash victims in the UK - said the failure to mention the specific dangers of these near-silent vehicles was a ‘very serious omission’ in the government’s statement on road safety.

Acoustic vehicle alert systems will be compulsory for the electric cars in the UK from 2021 and will activate when they're reversing or travelling at speeds up to 12.5mph

Nick Simmons, chief executive of RoadPeace, said: ‘We welcome the Government’s commitment to reducing the numbers of people killed or injured on our roads and look forward to seeing some real action towards it being achieved.

‘We hope it won’t be empty words – but we are concerned that the statement didn’t highlight the new dangers posed to pedestrians, cyclists and other vulnerable road users by quiet electric vehicles.

'There are already around 200,000 vehicles on the roads that are not required by law to have any warning sounds.'

Tell us which fake sound you'd want you electric car to make in the comments section below.
